Turing Award 1997

Winner: Maurice Wilkes

Why the Turing Award?

He receive the most prestigious award in informatics thanks to his work on designing and building (with his team) the EDSAC, or Electronic Delay Storage Automatic Calculator. In 1951, he also wrote a book called "Preparation of Programs for Electronic Digital Computers", that is known for being the first book on computer programming, and in which program libraries were introduced. In addition, he invented microprogramming, implementing it in the EDSAC 2.

More on his work

What is the EDSAC?

This machine was inspired on John Von Neumann researches. It used a mercury delay line memory , and it is known for being one of the first computers with an internally stored program. It also contained the first assembler in the world.

The EDSAC was mostly used as a part of the "Mathematical Laboratory's support service for calculation". As many other things, it was used to discover the largest prime number at the time, with 79 digits. A successor of the machine was commissioned in 1958, and it was named EDSAC 2.

Why is microprogramming important?

Microprogramming it's very useful, since it allows to define how a microprocessor should function, using a low-level code (called microcode). This means that the microcode can be defined as a translation layer that works between the machine instructions and the circuit level. Today, this technique is globally used, for example to implement control unit in computers.
